ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Effect of bi-layer ratio in ZnO/Al2O3 multilayers on microstructure and functional properties of ZnO nanocrystals embedded in Al2O3 matrix

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Departamento de Física e Astronomia, Faculdade de Ciências da Universidade do Porto
Affiliation.OrgName: IFIMUP and IN—Institute of Nanoscience and Nanotechnology

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Zinc oxide (ZnO) nanocrystals (NCs) embedded in alumina (Al2O3) matrix were produced via rapid thermal annealing (RTA) of pulsed laser deposited ZnO/Al2O3 multilayered nanostructures. The effect of the thickness ratio (R) between Al2O3 and ZnO in one bi-layer on the microstructure and functional properties of NCs has been investigated. Grazing incidence small angle X-ray scattering confirmed the formation of nanocrystals after RTA. Grazing incidence wide angle X-ray scattering studies revealed that ZnO NCs have a high crystalline quality with (100) as preferred orientation. Tensile strain of NCs decreases with increasing R and is correlated to the distribution of NCs. From Raman analysis, it is noticed that the phonon frequency of the E2 mode, related to the ZnO wurtzite phase, in NCs is shifted towards that of bulk ZnO with increasing R. Photoluminescence studies revealed that the near edge peak position shifts from 382 nm to 371 nm as the ratio R changes from 1.5 to 4 and is attributed to the strain effect. The intensity of emission in the yellow–green region due to defects decreases significantly with increasing R. Current–voltage (I–V) characteristics of Al/ZnO NCs embedded in Al2O3/n-Si (100)/Al have shown a hysteresis behavior. The increasing width of the hysteresis with increasing R revealed that the origin of the hysteresis might be due to the existence of polar surface charges on well-separated NCs. The high-resistance and low-resistance states in I–V hysteresis curves seem to be governed by Fowler–Nordheim tunneling and Schottky emission mechanisms, respectively.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Semiconductor nanocrystals (NCs) have attracted much attention for applications in a wide range of areas like spintronics, optoelectronics, sensors, transducers, and biomedical sciences [1–3]. The properties of NCs get modified significantly due to the confinement of charge carriers within the NCs and thus depend strongly on the NC size [4]. Their size-induced properties could promote the development of new applications or the addition of flexibility to existing systems in many areas. It is well known that ZnO is a semiconducting and piezoelectric material with a direct wide band gap of 3.37 eV and a large exciton binding energy of 60 meV at room temperature. Moreover, ZnO is an environmentally friendly material as compared to other semiconductor materials [5–7]. Due to these unique qualities, ZnO-based nanostructures have been considered as potential candidates for next-generation spintronic and optoelectronic devices.

Mostly, ZnO NCs have been synthesized by sol–gel and other wet chemical synthesis methods [7–10]. The main issues in these processes are the control of the particle shape, size, and distribution, and of the surface defects, while the high purity is maintained [11]. In these methods, NC size can be decreased only by simultaneously decreasing the NC density. But, for device applications, an accurate engineering of the spatial position, size, and density of NCs is essential. Therefore, NCs embedded in a dielectric matrix are more preferable than the creation of randomly distributed NCs. It has also been demonstrated that the implementation of ZnO NCs in memories requires long spin coherence times and that can be realized by embedding them in optical cavities [12]. Hence, embedded NCs have attracted considerable attention and have been successfully grown by physical vapor deposition techniques such as RF sputtering and pulsed laser deposition (PLD) [13, 14]. The main advantages of these processes are the ability to control the material purity and the flexibility in the selection on the NC size. However, the dependence of the morphology of grown NCs on preparation conditions has not been established yet. Since size and strain of NCs strongly affect the physical properties of semiconductor devices, the production of uniform NCs with a certain size and morphology is an important task.

In the present article, ZnO/Al2O3 multilayered nanostructures were grown by PLD on a Si (100) substrate and subsequently subjected to rapid thermal annealing (RTA) for the formation of embedded NCs. The effect of the thickness ratio (R) between Al2O3 and ZnO in one bi-layer on the size, shape, and spatial distribution of the ZnO NCs and consequently on their microstructure, optical, and electrical properties has been investigated. An attempt has been made to correlate the functional properties with the morphology of NCs. The origin of hysteresis in the current–voltage characteristics and a possible conduction mechanism have been highlighted.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para: The pulsed laser deposition (PLD) technique has been employed to grow multilayer nanostructures of ZnO and Al2O3. Commercial ZnO and Al2O3 targets (purity 99.99 %, Kurt J. Lesker Co.) were used as NC and dielectric sources, respectively. As the PLD system contains a multiple-target mounting carousel facility, it allows growing the alternate layers without breaking the vacuum. The deposition was performed with the help of a KrF laser (248 nm) with laser energy of 400 mJ at a frequency of 1 Hz in an oxygen atmosphere of 1×10−2 mbar. Before deposition, the chamber was first evacuated down to an ambient low pressure of ∼3×10−6 mbar. First, the deposition rate was estimated by depositing thick films on glass substrates and calculating the film thickness from the optical transmittance [15]. Then, the multilayered nanostructures with different ratios (R) of thickness between Al2O3 and ZnO in one bi-layer were prepared by depositing 10 alternating layers of ZnO and Al2O3 on n-type Si at room temperature. The thickness of ZnO was in the range of 2–4 nm and of Al2O3 in the range of 4–10 nm in one bi-layer. Subsequently, these samples were annealed using the rapid thermal annealing (RTA) technique in the presence of N2 at 800 °C during 60 s.

The samples were structurally characterized by grazing incidence wide angle X-ray scattering (GIWAXS) and grazing incidence small angle X-ray scattering (GISAXS). GIWAXS and GISAXS measurements were performed at the SAXS beamline at the ELETTRA synchrotron (Trieste, Italy) with 8 keV photon beam energy at a grazing incident angle slightly above the critical angle for total external reflection of Al2O3. A two-dimensional (2D) Pilatus 100 K detector and a 2D Mar300 image plate detector were used to record the GIWAXS and the GISAXS data, respectively. Unpolarized Raman spectra have been recorded in the backscattering geometry, at room temperature, by using an Olympus microscope and a 100× objective. The 514.5 nm polarized line of an Ar+ laser was used for excitation, with an incident power of about 16 mW impinging on the sample. The scattered light was analyzed using a T64000 Jobin-Yvon spectrometer, operating in a triple subtractive mode, and equipped with a liquid nitrogen cooled CCD detector, in the Stokes frequency range from 200 to 600 cm−1. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were recorded on a Spex Fluorolog spectrometer in the front-face geometry at room temperature, in the spectral range from 340 to 600 nm under 320 nm excitation from a xenon lamp. For electrical measurements, top aluminum (Al) electrodes, having a diameter of 1 mm, were deposited by a thermal evaporation technique and bottom Al electrodes were attached by an electric spark technique. The current–voltage (I–V) characteristics of Al/ZnO NCs embedded in Al2O3/n-Si (100)/Al have been measured at room temperature using a Keithley 607 programmable electrometer.

Section2.Heading: GISAXS and GIWAXS study
Section2.Para:
Figure 1a shows a 2D GISAXS image representing the map of scattering intensities in reciprocal space from a ZnO/Al2O3 as-grown multilayer structure on an n-type Si substrate. Two sheets of enhanced intensity elongated parallel to the horizontal axis are clearly seen. These, so-called Bragg sheets, are the consequence of correlated roughness of the multilayer interfaces, so they confirm the presence of a multilayered structure [16]. From the positions of the sheets we have calculated the period of the multilayer to be 5.5±0.1 nm. The GISAXS map of the annealed ZnO/Al2O3 nanostructure (Fig. 1b) shows only a small remnant of the Bragg sheets, close to the Q y=0 axis. This shows that the properties of the interface between the layers changed significantly during annealing. A strong semicircular signal dominates in the GISAXS map of the annealed nanostructures showing clearly the formation of nanoclusters (NCs) during annealing. This indicates that ZnO NCs are formed in the ZnO-rich layers. According to our previous experience with a similar system [14], the shape of the formed NCs is irregular but close to a spheroidal (plate-like) shape with the longer axis parallel to the film surface. As we analyze a very similar system here, we have assumed again a spheroidal shape of the NCs for the numerical analysis of the GISAXS map of the annealed film (the simulated map is shown in the inset of Fig. 1b). We have used a gamma distribution for the description of the dispersion of the NC radii. The radii in directions parallel and perpendicular to the substrate surface are denoted by R L and R V, respectively. The values of the mean radii are found to be R L=1.3±0.2 nm and R V=1.1±0.2 nm, while the standard deviation of the used distribution is found to be 1.1±0.1 nm. For the description of the NC arrangement, we have used the paracrystal model described in Ref. [16]. From the GISAXS analysis it follows that there is practically no correlation of the NC positions, i.e. they form randomly within the layers. The simulation results are in excellent agreement with the experimental data as evident from the intensity profiles shown in Figs. 1c and d; therefore, we believe that the choice of the NC shape and NC arrangement was correct. Additionally, the average vertical size of the formed NCs is very close to the nominal thickness of a ZnO-rich layer (2 nm).
Fig. 1
Typical 2D GISAXS intensity maps of the ZnO/Al2O3 multilayered nanostructures: (a) as-grown and (b) annealed in nitrogen ambient at 800 °C for 60 s; the inset shows a simulated GISAXS map, (c, d) intensity profiles showing experimental data and the corresponding fits

Figure 2a shows GIWAXS patterns of annealed ZnO/Al2O3 nanostructures measured in the range of 2θ=20–45°. The presence of strong peaks reveals high crystalline quality of the nanostructures. The peaks around 2θ=31.1±0.3° and 36.7±0.3° were attributed to ZnO (100) and alpha-Al2O3 (110) reflections, respectively. The presence of reflections along (100) confirms that NCs have preferred orientations. The preferred orientation and peak position of ZnO NCs are in good agreement with grazing incidence X-ray diffraction (GIXRD) patterns of Mn-doped ZnO nanocrystals embedded in Al2O3 matrix, measured in a wide range of 2θ=30–70° in our previous work [14]. However, the (100) peak position was found to be slightly shifted towards lower angles as compared to the bulk ZnO position at 2θ=31.8° [17], which suggests an elongated unit cell in the (100) direction. This might be the consequence of strain in the ZnO/Al2O3 nanostructures. Extended GIWAXS curves of the nanostructures with different thickness ratios are shown in Fig. 2b. The peak position shifts towards the bulk position with increasing bi-layer ratio (R). The shift in the diffraction position is due to a change in the lattice parameters and is attributed to the strain effect.
Fig. 2
WAXS patterns of (a) annealed ZnO/Al2O3 nanostructures with different R and (b) extended curves

The strain present in these nanostructures was calculated using the following formula [18]:
1
$$ \varepsilon = \frac{a _{f} - a _{b}}{a _{b}} $$ where a
f is the lattice constant of the NCs and a
b is 3.2455 Å, the strain-free lattice parameter measured from ZnO powder [17]. The variation of the strain, estimated using Eq. (1), with R is shown in Fig. 3. The strain decreases from +3.1 % to +1.2 % as R changes from 1.5 to 4. The strain present in these structures was found to be of tensile nature. It is strongly believed that this strain arises from the formation and distribution of ZnO NCs in the Al2O3 matrix. Usually, the strain in the films could be due to the difference in the thermal expansion coefficients of the substrate and of the film, but, if it is the main source of strain, it should decrease with increasing film thickness. In the present case, the thicknesses for samples with R=1.5, 2, and 4 are 95, 65, and 105 nm, respectively, and the strain continuously decreases with increasing R as shown in Fig. 3. So, in these samples, the main source of strain could not be attributed to thermal effects. Moreover, since both Al2O3 and ZnO have similar thermal expansion coefficients (≈8×10−6 K), the possible reason for strain can only be the coalescence of NCs. It has been reported that the isolated crystals are stress-free and the coalescence process gives rise to tensile stress, driven by the reduction in interfacial/surface energies [19]. The decreasing trend of strain with increase of R might be due to the good separation of the ZnO NCs as the matrix content increases.
Fig. 3
Plot of strain versus bi-layer ratio R

Section2.Heading: Raman spectroscopy
Section2.Para:
Raman spectra of annealed ZnO/Al2O3 nanostructures were recorded in the Stokes frequency range of 200–600 cm−1. Figure 4a presents a typical Raman spectrum of annealed nanostructures. The spectrum exhibits a peak at 434±2 cm−1 related to ZnO in addition to Si substrate peaks. Extended unpolarized Raman spectra of ZnO NCs in the range of 400–450 cm−1 are shown in Fig. 4b. It is well known that bulk ZnO exhibits a peak at 437 cm−1, which corresponds to the E2 (high) mode, and is associated with the ZnO wurtzite structure [20]. The presence of peaks at 434±2 cm−1 reveals the high crystalline quality of the ZnO NCs. As compared to the bulk, the E2 mode has an asymmetric line shape and the phonon frequency of ZnO NCs has shifted towards the low-frequency side as shown in Fig. 4b. Usually, shift and asymmetry on the low-frequency side are attributed to the phonon confinement effect and/or the strain effect [21]. The effect of R on the phonon frequency of the NCs is shown in Fig. 4c. It has been observed that the phonon frequency of the NCs is shifted towards the phonon frequency of bulk ZnO with increasing R. Usually, the stress induced in wurtzite structure crystals affects the E2 phonon frequency [22]. A positive shift in the E2 phonon frequency is ascribed to compressive stress, whereas a negative shift is ascribed to tensile stress. The present GIWAXS analysis also revealed that the strain present in the nanostructures has tensile nature. Hence, the negative shift of the phonon frequency in the nanostructures could be attributed to tensile stress.
Fig. 4
(a) Typical Raman spectra of annealed ZnO/Al2O3 nanostructures, (b) extended Raman spectra of annealed nanostructures with different R, and (c) E2 peak position as a function of R

Section2.Heading: Photoluminescence (PL) measurements
Section2.Para:
Room-temperature PL spectra of annealed ZnO/Al2O3 nanostructures are shown in Fig. 5. For comparison, PL spectra of ZnO and Al2O3 thin films (monolayers), annealed under the same conditions, are also included. The PL spectrum of the ZnO thin film shows two emission bands as depicted in Fig. 5a. A sharp peak at 376 nm is assigned to radiative annihilation of free excitons near the band edge (NBE) [23]. The second broad peak observed in the yellow–green region is commonly associated with the transition of excited optical centers from a deep level to the valence level [24]. This kind of deep-level emission is usually due to the presence of structural defects like zinc interstitials and oxygen vacancies. All these defects are related to an insufficient supply of oxygen during growth [25]. The PL spectrum of Al2O3 shows a peak centered at around 395 nm, and this is in good agreement with the values reported for α-Al2O3 [25].
Fig. 5
Photoluminescence spectra of (a) ZnO, (b) Al2O3, and (c–e) ZnO/Al2O3 nanostructures with different R. Each PL spectrum was fitted using Gaussian approximations and (f) shift of the ZnO peak position (NBE) vs R

The annealed structures exhibit a broad asymmetric shape of the near band edge PL peak as compared to pure ZnO thin films as shown in Figs. 5c–e. This could be due to the convolution of two peaks associated with ZnO and Al2O3. Each PL spectrum was fitted using Gaussian approximations as shown in Figs. 5c–e. Three Gaussian peaks were required to de-convolute the measured PL spectrum by varying the amplitude and peak position. The de-convoluted peaks correspond to ZnO NBE emission, Al2O3, and deep-level emission, and their positions are tabulated in Table 1. The increase of the relative peak intensity ratio of Al2O3 and ZnO (
$I_{\mathrm{Al}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}}/I_{\mathrm{ZnO}}$ ) with increasing R has also justified the Al2O3 contribution to the PL signal (Table 1). The NBE peak position is shifted from 382 to 371 nm as the ratio R changes from 1.5 to 4. This shift can be attributed to the stress effect as evidenced from the Raman and GIWAXS analyses. The shift in peak position has shown a linear trend with R as depicted in Fig. 5f. Hence, it may suggest that the band gap of the nanostructures can be tailored via the control of R. The emission intensity in the yellow–green region significantly decreases with increasing R. This could be attributed to a decrease of structural defects. Probably, there might be diffusion of a few oxygen atoms from the Al2O3 matrix to the ZnO nanocrystals as the matrix content increases. As a result, structural defects were decreased in the ZnO nanostructures.

Section2.Heading: Current–voltage (I–V) characteristics
Section2.Para:
Current–voltage (I–V) characteristics of Al/ZnO NCs embedded in Al2O3/n-Si (100)/Al structures measured at room temperature are shown in Fig. 6. The voltage was swept from −8 V to +8 V and vice versa. The I–V characteristics display a hysteresis behavior with the bias voltage. The hysteresis I–V curves in the present nanostructures clearly show the device behaving like a typical memristor with the current depending on the scanning route [26]. From Fig. 6, it is observed that the current value in the nanostructures slightly decreases with increasing R and this can be attributed to a decrease of structural defects like oxygen vacancies as evidenced from the PL analysis. However, the width of the hysteresis is found to be different for samples having different R. Obviously, as R increases, the width of the matrix between the nanocrystals also increases. It is observed that the width of the hysteresis increases with increasing R. This suggests that the observed hysteresis might be related to the polar surfaces of the ZnO NCs [27]. As the width of the matrix between the NCs decreases, the polar charges on the surface will decrease due to the screening effect. If there would be no polar charges, no electrons would be required to screen them; thus, the hysteresis effect would disappear. Hence, polar charges at the surface can be preserved by controlling the width of the matrix between the NCs.
Fig. 6
I–V characteristics of annealed ZnO/Al2O3 nanostructures

To investigate the transport mechanisms, which control two different states of resistances such as low resistance (LR) and high resistance (HR) states, we have carried out nonlinear fittings to the I–V characteristics. A typical conduction mechanism such as Fowler–Nordheim (F-N) tunneling is considered. For F-N tunneling, the I–V function can be described as follows [28]:
2
$$ J=C V ^{2} \exp \biggl( - \frac{4 \sqrt{2 m ^{*}} ( \varphi_{B} ) ^{3/2} d}{3qhV} \biggr) $$ where J is the current density, V is the applied voltage, C is a constant depending on the elementary charge q, the barrier height φ
B , and Planck’s constant h, and m ∗ stands for the carriers’ effective mass. Figure 7a shows the semilog plots of (J/V 2) versus 1/V. In ZnO/Al2O3 nanostructures with R=2, both LR and HR states follow the F-N tunneling in the high-voltage region. In the nanostructures with R=3 and 4, the HR state follows F-N tunneling (Fig. 7b) but the LR state seems to follow Schottky emission. If the leakage current is controlled by Schottky emission, the following relation applies [29]:
3
$$ \operatorname{Ln} (I)\alpha \biggl( \frac{\sqrt{\frac{e ^{3}}{4\pi\varepsilon _{0} \varepsilon _{\mathrm{r}} d}}}{kT} \biggr). \sqrt{V} $$ Figure 8 shows the linear Schottky plot of ln I versus V 1/2. The estimated ε r from the slope (≈2.4) is found to be 4.08. Thus, the refractive index for ZnO/Al2O3 nanostructures is 2.02, which is comparable to that of ZnO nanostructures as determined by optical methods. Therefore, the Schottky emission mechanism is valid in the present case.
Fig. 7
Fowler–Nordheim tunneling fit to I–V characteristics of annealed ZnO/Al2O3 nanostructures with (a) R=2 and (b) R=4
Fig. 8
Schottky fit to the I–V characteristics of ZnO/Al2O3 nanostructures with R=4

I–V characteristics of ZnO/Al2O3 nanostructures with R=4 were also studied by applying a different range of bias voltages and the results are shown in Fig. 9. The hysteresis width is found to be saturated at higher bias voltages. This confirms that the observed hysteresis could be due to surface polar charges. The present ferroelectric memory technology is limited by the storage density due to limitations in size reduction of ferroelectric materials. As the domain size and width of domain boundaries reduce, the ferroelectric property screens due to the surface screening effect. In contrast, the polar charge induced electric hysteresis in the embedded ZnO NCs makes them good candidates for fast and high-storage memory applications.
Fig. 9
I–V characteristics of annealed ZnO/Al2O3 nanostructures with R=4 measured at different ranges of bias voltages

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In this work, ZnO NCs embedded in Al2O3 matrix with high crystalline quality have been prepared via rapid thermal annealing of ZnO/Al2O3 multilayer nanostructures. The effect of the bi-layer ratio on their structure and optical and electrical properties was investigated. GISAXS depicted that rapid thermal annealing promoted the formation of NCs with random distribution. WAXS and Raman analysis revealed that the strain of NCs is of tensile nature and decreases with increasing R. The PL analysis suggests that the band gap of NCs can be tuned via control of R. The width of the hysteresis in the I–V curves increases with increasing R. The high resistance (HR) and low resistance (LR) states in the I–V hysteresis curves are governed by Fowler–Nordheim tunneling and Schottky emission mechanisms, respectively. The observed hysteresis in the I–V characteristics due to polar surface charges on well-separated NCs makes them a potential candidate for high speed memory applications.
